verbatim.problem_statement: It is perhaps the most basic pattern there is in forming group cohesion.
verbatim.solution_statement: Create a single common area for every social group. Locate it at the center of gravity of all the spaces the group occupies, and in such a way that the paths which go in and out of the building lie tangent to it.

forces.name: communal gathering vs. private retreat
forces.pole_a: the need for a shared place where the group can gather, eat, and feel cohesion
forces.pole_b: the need to reach private rooms without being forced into communal interaction
forces.description: People need a heart for group life, but access to private spaces must not be blocked or detoured by it
forces.resolved_by: placing the common area at the center of gravity with tangent rather than through-paths

forces.name: accessibility vs. centrality
forces.pole_a: the common area must be equally reachable by all members of the group
forces.pole_b: the common area must not become a dead-end that requires a special detour to reach
forces.description: A room placed off the main circulation is avoided; one placed squarely in the flow becomes a mandatory pass-through that destroys privacy
forces.resolved_by: siting at the center of gravity with paths running tangent to its edges

forces.name: indoor comfort vs. desire to be outside
forces.pole_a: the common area provides warmth, food, and seating for communal indoor life
forces.pole_b: on nice days people long to step outside, sit on grass, or carry on discussions outdoors
forces.description: A purely indoor common room fails to satisfy the pull toward outdoor life
forces.resolved_by: including an adjacent outdoor area as part of the common area

forces.name: spontaneous encounter vs. deliberate visit
forces.pole_a: group cohesion is built through casual, unplanned contact as people pass through
forces.pole_b: if reaching the common area requires purposeful effort, people skip it and isolation grows
forces.description: The common area must generate incidental contact, not only scheduled meetings
forces.resolved_by: routing daily in-and-out paths so they pass tangent to the common area

typed_rules.metric: Location of common area relative to group territory
typed_rules.preferred_value: center of gravity of all spaces the group occupies
typed_rules.rationale: Must be equally accessible to everyone and felt as the center of the group
typed_rules.source_text: It must be at the center of gravity of the building complex, building, or building wing which the group occupies

typed_rules.preferred_value: tangent — paths pass alongside but do not dead-end into it
typed_rules.rationale: If the common area is a dead-end, people must go out of their way and will avoid it; tangent paths generate incidental contact
typed_rules.source_text: it must be 'on the way' from the entrance to private rooms, so people always go by it on the way in and out of the building. It is crucial that it not be a dead-end room which one would have to go out of one's way to get to. For this reason, the paths which pass it must lie tangent to it.

typed_rules.metric: Number of common areas per social group
typed_rules.rationale: A single shared heart creates group identity; multiple competing areas dilute cohesion
typed_rules.source_text: Create a single common area for every social group.

typed_rules.metric: Required functional components — kitchen and eating space
typed_rules.rationale: Eating is one of the most communal of activities and anchors the common area
typed_rules.source_text: usually a kitchen and eating space, since eating is one of the most communal of activities

typed_rules.rationale: Comfortable seating signals that lingering is welcome and encourages people to stay
typed_rules.source_text: a sitting space—at least some comfortable chairs, so people will feel like staying

typed_rules.preferred_value: direct access to outdoor area included as part of the common area
typed_rules.rationale: On nice days there is always the longing to be outside; an outdoor component satisfies this without leaving the communal zone
typed_rules.source_text: It should also include an outdoor area—on nice days there is always the longing to be outside—to step out for a smoke, to sit down on the grass, to carry on a discussion.

adjacency_rules.note: Food and fire are described as most basic to common areas; farmhouse kitchen is explicitly named first

adjacency_rules.target_pattern_name: Light on Two Sides of Every Room
adjacency_rules.note: Governs fine-grained shape and quality of the common area space

failure_modes.description: When the common area is placed as a dead-end room, people must make a deliberate detour to reach it and routinely bypass it, so group cohesion never forms.
failure_modes.symptom: Common room sits empty; members never encounter one another casually; group identity fragments
failure_modes.source_text: It is crucial that it not be a dead-end room which one would have to go out of one's way to get to.

failure_modes.description: When the common area is placed off-center — closer to some members' spaces than others — those farther away feel excluded and stop using it, undermining its role as a group heart.
failure_modes.violated_rule: Location of common area relative to group territory
failure_modes.symptom: Common area is colonised by the subgroup nearest to it; distant members form separate informal gathering spots
failure_modes.source_text: it must be at the physical heart of the organization, so that it is equally accessible to everyone and can be felt as the center of the group

failure_modes.description: When no kitchen or eating provision is included, the common area lacks the anchor of shared meals and loses the most reliably communal activity that draws people together repeatedly.
failure_modes.violated_rule: Required functional components — kitchen and eating space
failure_modes.symptom: Attendance is sporadic and event-driven rather than daily; the space feels institutional rather than homely
failure_modes.source_text: eating is one of the most communal of activities

failure_modes.description: When seating is absent or uncomfortable, people pass through without pausing, and the space functions as a corridor rather than a hearth.
failure_modes.symptom: People stand briefly and move on; no lingering conversations develop; the area feels transitional, not communal
failure_modes.source_text: at least some comfortable chairs, so people will feel like staying
